question: Tasks you think "I'll do it later" often end up never getting done.
explanation: Procrastination isn't a willpower problem -- it's a natural tendency to avoid discomfort. Changing how you start a task may help improve this.

best_for: People whose tasks tend to pile up
limitations: There are cases where procrastination is adaptive (e.g., waiting for more information)
expanded_details.citation_role: Observation from a meta-analysis of procrastination behavior

question: When you're waiting for motivation to strike before starting, what might actually be happening?
choices: Your body is asking for rest
explanation: Motivation isn't something you wait for -- it tends to emerge once you start. Moving your hands for just 10 seconds can switch you into task mode. (We tend to think "I need rest" or "it's not important," but it's often just avoidance.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Next time you catch yourself waiting for motivation, try moving your hands for just 10 seconds. If you hate it, stop right away -- that's OK.

best_for: People who spend a long time waiting for motivation
People who struggle to get started
limitations: When you're genuinely tired, rest is necessary
Chronic lack of motivation may require a different approach
expanded_details.citation_role: Explains behavioral activation theory in procrastination research

question: If you decide to "just do 5 minutes," you often end up continuing beyond 5 minutes.
explanation: Lowering the barrier to start tends to make it easier to get into the flow of a task. It's perfectly fine if you actually stop at 5 minutes. It's also normal if you can't do it. Just try once.

best_for: People who feel overwhelmed by big tasks
limitations: Tasks that can't be done in 5 minutes may need additional steps
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the 5-minute rule based on implementation intention research
expanded_details.try_this: 👉 When a task feels heavy, spend just 10 seconds writing down a "5-minute version"

tiny_metric.metric: Were you able to press the 5-minute timer and start?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't press it 3 times in a row, stop

comparator.baseline: Looking at the entire task and feeling overwhelmed

question: Which method has been reported to reduce procrastination?
choices: Decide "when, where, and what to do" in advance
explanation: "Implementation intentions" (if-then planning) have been suggested to reduce procrastination. Effectiveness varies by individual. Just try once. ("Shorter deadlines" and "rewards" can work too, but deciding "when and where" first tends to be more effective.)
actionable_advice: 💡 For your next task, decide one thing: "At [time], at [place], I will [do this]."

best_for: People who can't act when tasks are vague
limitations: Not going according to plan can cause stress
Not suited for situations requiring flexibility
expanded_details.citation_role: Directly supports the effectiveness of implementation intentions
expanded_details.try_this: 👉 In the next 10 seconds, decide just one: "At [time], at [place], I will [do this]"

tiny_metric.metric: Were you able to create one if-then plan?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't create one 3 times in a row, stop

comparator.baseline: Just thinking "I need to do it"

question: The more you think "I have to do it perfectly," the more likely you are to procrastinate.
explanation: A link between perfectionism and procrastination has been reported. Deciding "70% is good enough" tends to make it easier to get moving.

limitations: In situations where quality truly matters, perfectionism may be necessary
expanded_details.citation_role: Supports the link between perfectionism and procrastination through observational studies

question: When a task feels "too big to start," what helps you get moving?
choices: Focus on just the next single step
Ask someone else to do it
explanation: Breaking a large task into smaller pieces tends to make it easier to process. Deciding "just the next move" can help you get started. Just try once. ("Being aware of deadlines" and "asking for help" also work, but breaking it down is the best first step.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Write down just the "next one step" for a big task you're currently facing.

best_for: People overwhelmed by the big picture
limitations: Over-dividing tasks can make things more complex
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the effect of task decomposition from implementation intention research
expanded_details.try_this: 👉 In 10 seconds, write down just "the next one step"

tiny_metric.metric: Were you able to write down "the next one step"?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't write it down 3 times in a row, stop

comparator.baseline: Looking at the whole task and freezing up

fallback.when: You can't think of even one step

question: A colleague says, "You still haven't finished that task?" How do you respond?
choices: "I was just about to start. I'll try doing just 5 minutes."
"No, but I'll get it done by the end of the week."
explanation: Declaring your intention can become a "social commitment" that makes it easier to take action. However, this can backfire for people sensitive to pressure. Just try once.

best_for: People who are motivated by commitments to others
People for whom extrinsic motivation works well
limitations: Can backfire for people sensitive to pressure
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the effect of social commitment
expanded_details.try_this: 👉 In 10 seconds, tell someone "I'll just do 5 minutes"

tiny_metric.metric: Were you able to work for 5 minutes after declaring?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't get moving 3 times in a row, stop

fallback.when: Declaring feels like too much pressure
fallback.next: Switch to the 10-second rule without declaring

question: There's a view that procrastination is not "laziness" but an "emotion regulation" issue.
explanation: Recent research tends to understand procrastination as a behavior of "avoiding unpleasant emotions." In other words, emotion regulation may be more key than willpower.

best_for: People who tend to blame themselves
People who experience self-loathing from procrastinating
limitations: Not all procrastination is about emotion regulation
expanded_details.citation_role: Theoretically supports the emotion regulation model of procrastination

question: What specific method has been reported to be effective for reducing procrastination?
choices: Decide "just 10 seconds" and move your hands
Put the deadline on the calendar
explanation: The 10-second rule has been suggested as effective for lowering the "barrier to starting." To-do lists and deadlines work too, but the 10-second rule has the lowest effort. Just try once. ("To-do lists" and "calendars" require preparation.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Try this just once tomorrow: when you feel stuck, move your hands for just 10 seconds.

best_for: People who want an easy way to start
limitations: May have limited effect on chronic lack of motivation
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the 10-second rule from a procrastination meta-analysis
expanded_details.try_this: When you feel stuck, move your hands for just 10 seconds

tiny_metric.before_prompt: How much do you NOT want to do this right now? (0-10)
tiny_metric.success_rule: Any decrease at all counts as a win
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If it stays the same or goes up, retreat for today

fallback.next: Break the task down to its smallest unit

question: From what you learned today, which could you use starting tomorrow?
choices: Decide "just 10 seconds" and move your hands
explanation: All of them are worth trying. With procrastination, finding ways to "live with it" may matter more than trying to "overcome" it. If something doesn't fit, try a different method. Just try once. (Each individual option is also valid -- the easiest is the 10-second rule.)
actionable_advice: 💡 Today's action: try "just 10 seconds" on your next task.

best_for: People who want to start a new habit
limitations: You might not be able to keep all of them up
expanded_details.citation_role: Indirectly supports the effectiveness of procrastination interventions
expanded_details.try_this: Try "just 10 seconds" on your next task

tiny_metric.metric: Did you use the 10-second rule at least once this week?
tiny_metric.stop_rule: If you can't remember to do it once in a week, stop

fallback.next: Switch to the 5-minute rule or if-then planning
